questions.text: A 58-year-old male patient presents with difficulty in urination and reports a sensation of incomplete bladder emptying. Upon examination, the neurologist suspects an issue with autonomic innervation to the urinary bladder. What are the root values for the sympathetic and parasympathetic innervation of the urinary bladder?
questions.explanation:
Type of Innervation

Nerves

Function

Parasympathetic Nerve Fibers (S2, S3, S4)

Pelvic splanchnic nerves
  • Excitatory effect on Detrusor muscle
  • Inhibitory to the vesical sphincter.

Sympathetic Fibers (T10-L2)
  • Inferior mesenteric plexus
  • Hypogastric plexus
  • Inhibitory effect on Detrusor muscle
  • Motor action on vesical sphincter

Somatic Nerve (S1, S2, S3)

Pudendal nerve

Supplies external urethral sphincter, which is under voluntary control

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with sharp pain and swelling in her right buttock and thigh after falling on her side, leading to difficulty sitting and walking. Examination shows swelling, tenderness, and bruising over the right buttock, with no deformity, dislocation, or neurological deficits, indicating a possible hematoma. What is the origin of the affected artery?

options.label: A
options.text: Anterior division of the internal iliac artery

options.label: B
options.text: Posterior division of the internal iliac artery

options.label: C
options.text: Anterior division of the obturator artery

options.label: D
options.text: Posterior division of the obturator artery

questions.correct_answer: B. Posterior division of the internal iliac artery
questions.explanation:
Superior Gluteal Artery

Origin

Branch of the posterior division of the internal iliac artery.

Course

Supply

Superficial Branch:

  • Gluteus maximus

Deep Branch:

  • Gluteus medius
  • Gluteus minimus

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with rectal bleeding and changes in bowel habits. The physician evaluates the rectal anatomy to determine the best surgical approach. Which part of the rectum is covered by peritoneum only on the anterior aspect?
questions.explanation:
Part of Rectum

Peritoneal Relation

Upper 1/3rd (Option A)

Covered with peritoneum on the anterior and lateral aspects.

Middle 1/3rd (Option B)

Covered only on the anterior aspect.

Lower 1/3rd (Option C)

Devoid of peritoneum

Part of Rectum

Male

Female

Upper 2/3rd

Rectovesical pouch (coils of intestine and sigmoid colon)

Rectouterine pouch (coils of intestine and sigmoid colon)

Lower 1/3rd
  • Base of the urinary bladder
  • Ureters (terminal parts)
  • Seminal vesicles
  • Vas deferens (ampullae)
  • Prostate

Vagina (lower part)
 

In the Midline

On each side of the Midline
  • Lower three pieces of the sacrum
  • Coccyx
  • Anococcygeal raphe
  • Ganglion impar
  • Median sacral vessels
  • Superior rectal artery
  • Fascia of Waldeyer
  • Pyriformis
  • Coccygeus
  • Levator ani
  • Sympathetic chains
  • Anterior primary rami of S3, S4, S5, and coccygeal nerve
  • Pelvic splanchnic nerves
  • Lateral sacral vessels

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents with faecal incontinence, particularly during activities that increase intra-abdominal pressure, such as coughing or lifting heavy objects. MRI reveals atrophy in a muscle responsible for maintaining the anorectal angle. What’s the likely muscle involved in this?
questions.explanation:
Resting Tone is mainly provided by Internal Anal Sphincter (IAS)

Relaxed External anal sphincter (EAS) and Puborectalis muscle

Weakness of External anal Sphincter, Internal anal Sphincter, Puborectalis muscle.

Anorectal Ring Muscles

Muscle

Description

Function

Significance

Internal Anal Sphincter (Option D)

Thickened, terminal portion of the inner circular smooth muscle layer of the large intestine.

Provides continuous resting tone to the anal canal through sympathetic innervation.

Dysfunction can lead to faecal incontinence.

External Anal Sphincter (Option A)

Main bulk of the anal sphincter complex and is primarily made of striated muscle.

Allows voluntary control over defecation; allows sustained contraction.

Important for voluntary faecal control

Conjoint Longitudinal Muscle (Option B)

Layer between internal and external anal sphincters; continuous with the outer longitudinal smooth muscle of the rectum.

Contracts during defecation, shortening and widening the anal canal, facilitating faecal passage.

Plays a role in defecation; age-related decline in muscle fibres can impact function.

Puborectalis (Option C)

Sling muscle part of the levator ani muscle, surrounding the anorectal junction.

Maintains the anorectal angle.

Critical for faecal continence

questions.text: A 46-year-old female reports intermittent rectal bleeding and a feeling of fullness during bowel movements. She has a history of constipation and obesity. Examination reveals internal haemorrhoids. Which of the following options correctly describes their characteristics concerning location and nerve supply? Presence of a visible thrombus in the anal region Ability to manually reduce the mass. Located below the dentate line, covered by anoderm. Innervated by pelvic splanchnic nerves; generally painless.
questions.explanation:
Type of piles

Internal Hemorrhoids

External Hemorrhoids

Location

Above pectinate line

Below pectinate line

Contributing Vein

Main tributaries and radicals of Superior rectal vein

Tributaries of Inferior rectal vein

Common Site

3, 7 and 11 o’clock positions of the anal wall, in the lithotomy position

No such common site.

Pain

Painless (as innervated by splanchnic nerves) (Statement 4)

Painful (innervated by somatic nerves)

Bleeding

Bleeds on straining at stool

Do not bleed on straining

Points to know
  • Initially, they are contained within the anal canal (1st degree), later, they expand and protrude during defecation (2nd degree), and finally, they stay protruded (3rd degree).
  • 2nd-degree piles can be manually reduced if they are prolapsed and not thrombosed. (Statement 2)
  • A thrombosed external haemorrhoid appears as a painful, swollen, bluish lump at the anal verge resulting from the rupture of a subcutaneous vein. (Statement 1)
  • These are located below the dentate line and present as tense hematomas at the anal margin (perianal hematomas). (Statement 3)

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman in labour is experiencing discomfort and perianal pain and is scheduled to receive a pudendal nerve block. Which anatomical landmarks should the clinician identify to locate the pudendal nerve accurately?
Which of the following accurately describes the X, Y, and Z listed below?

options.label: A
options.text: Posterior rami of S1, S2, S3

options.label: B
options.text: Anterior rami of S1, S2, S3

options.label: C
options.text: Posterior rami of S2, S3, S4

options.label: D
options.text: Anterior rami of S2, S3, S4

questions.correct_answer: D. Anterior rami of S2, S3, S4
questions.explanation:
Nerve Root & Nerve To

Supplies

(L4, L5, S1) Nerve to Quadratus Femoris
  • Quadratus femoris
  • Inferior gemellus
  • Hip joint

(L5, S1, S2) Nerve to Obturator Internus
  • Obturator internus
  • Superior gemellus

(S2, S3, S4) Pudendal nerve
  • Genital skin,
  • External genital organs
  • Muscles of the perineum

(S3, S4) Perforating cutaneous nerve

Small area of skin in the gluteal area

(L4, L5, S1, S2, S3) Tibial part of the sciatic nerve.
  • Hamstrings
  • All muscles of the calf and the sole

(S1, S2) Posterior cutaneous nerve of thigh

Skin at the back of the thigh

Nerve Root & Nerve To

Supplies

(L4, L5, S1) Superior Gluteal Nerve
  • Gluteus medius,
  • Gluteus minimus
  • Tensor fascia lata

(L5, S1, S2) Inferior Gluteal Nerve

Gluteus maximus

(L4, L5, S1, S2) Common Peroneal Part of the Sciatic Nerve
  • Evertors of foot
  • Dorsiflexors of ankle joint and extensor digitorum brevis

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with chronic perineal pain and numbness following a difficult vaginal delivery. The clinician suspects entrapment of the nerve supplying sensation to the perineum. Through which foramina does this nerve exit and re-enter the pelvis?

options.label: B
options.text: Lesser sciatic foramen → Greater sciatic foramen,

options.label: D
options.text: Greater sciatic foramen → Lesser sciatic foramen

questions.correct_answer: D. Greater sciatic foramen → Lesser sciatic foramen

questions.text: A 62-year-old female presents with persistent pelvic pain and urinary incontinence. Imaging reveals a mass in the pelvic region compressing nearby blood vessels, raising suspicion of internal iliac artery involvement. Which of the following is not a branch of the internal iliac artery?
questions.explanation:
Artery

Branches

Supplies

 

External Iliac Artery

Deep circumflex iliac artery

Muscles attached to

the iliac crest

Inferior epigastric artery

Muscles and overlying skin of rectus sheath

Internal Iliac Artery (Anterior Division)

Superior vesical artery
  • Urinary bladder’s superior surface
  • Muscular wall of ductus deferens

Obturator artery

Medial thigh

Middle rectal artery
  • Muscle coats of rectum
  • Prostate
  • Seminal vesicles

Inferior Vesical artery
  • Urinary bladder
  • Prostate
  • seminal vesicle
  • The lower part of the ureter

Inferior gluteal artery

Gluteal region

Internal Pudendal artery

Perineum region

Vaginal artery

Vagina and base of the urinary bladder

Uterine artery

Vagina and uterus

Internal Iliac Artery (Posterior Division) 

(Mnemonic - SIL)

Superior Gluteal artery

Muscles of the gluteal region
 

Iliolumbar artery
  • Iliacus
  • Muscles of back
  • Cauda equina
 

Lateral sacral artery
  • Cauda equina
  • Back muscles of the sacrum

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with urinary retention and pelvic discomfort. A digital rectal examination reveals an enlarged prostate gland. During surgery to relieve the obstruction, the urologist must take care to avoid damaging the structures that separate the prostate from the rectum. Which of the following structures separates the prostate gland from the rectum?

A 55-year-old male with intermittent abdominal pain, changes in bowel habits, and occasional rectal bleeding is scheduled for a sigmoidoscopy. The cannula is inserted in the left lateral position to avoid injuring the rectal folds that are present against the concavities of the rectum. Which of the following statements regarding these folds is inaccurate?

options.label: A
options.text: First fold is situated near the rectosigmoid junction.

options.label: C
options.text: Third fold is located at the upper end of the ampulla.

options.label: D
options.text: They are flattened in a distended rectum.

questions.correct_answer: D. They are flattened in a distended rectum.
questions.explanation:
Longitudinal

Houston’s valve  (Transverse or horizontal folds or plicae transversales)
  • Temporary folds
  • Situated in the lower part of an empty rectum.
  • Obliterated by distension
  • Permanent folds (Option B)
  • Situated against the concavities of the lateral curvatures of the rectum.
  • More prominent by distension (Option D)

Types

First Transverse Fold

Second Transverse Fold

Third Transverse Fold

Fourth Transverse Fold

Site

Near the upper end, close to the rectosigmoid junction. (Option A)

Above the third fold (2.5cm)

At the level of the upper end of the ampulla. (Option C)

Below the third valve (2.5cm)

Wall of Projection

Right or left wall

Left wall

(upper lateral curvature)

Anterior and right wall

(middle lateral curvature)

Left wall

(lower lateral curvature)

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with perianal pain and bleeding during bowel movements. The region affected is supplied by a vessel that arises from the internal iliac system and supplies the lower anal canal. Which of the following arteries is the direct source of this vessel?
questions.explanation:
Artery

Source

Supplies

Superior Rectal Artery

Branch of the inferior mesenteric artery (Option A)

Upper two-thirds of the rectum

Middle Rectal Artery

Branch of the internal iliac artery

Middle third of the rectum

Inferior Rectal Artery

Branch of the internal pudendal artery (Option B)

Distal rectum & anal canal

Vein

Drains Into

Region Drained

Superior Rectal Vein

Inferior mesenteric vein

Upper two-thirds of the rectum

Middle Rectal Vein

Internal iliac vein

Middle third of the rectum

Inferior Rectal Vein

Internal pudendal vein

Anal canal & distal rectum

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with painful anal swelling and bleeding. External haemorrhoids are diagnosed, and the physician explains the pain is due to somatic innervation below a specific anatomical landmark in the anal canal. Which of the following separates the areas of somatic and visceral nerve supply in the anal canal?
questions.explanation:
Features

Upper Anal Canal

Lower Anal Canal

Development

Endodermal

Ectodermal

Epithelium

Simple columnar

Stratified squamous

Nerve supply

Autonomic nerves

  • Painless
  • Sympathetic (L1, L2)
  • Parasympathetic (S2, S3, S4)

Somatic nerves

  • Painful
  • Sympathetic (S2, S, S4)

Arterial supply

Superior rectal artery

Inferior rectal artery

Venous drainage

Superior rectal vein draining into the portal system

Inferior rectal vein draining into caval system

Lymphatic system

Internal iliac nodes

Superficial inguinal nodes

Common Type of Hemorrhoids

Internal hemorrhoids

External hemorrhoids

questions.text: A 73-year-old male presents with rectal pain, and there is concern for rectal metastasis, given his history of prostate cancer. Which lymph nodes are most likely involved in the lymphatic drainage of the region marked ‘X’ in the image?
questions.explanation:
Region

Lymphatic Drainage

Upper half of the rectum

Inferior mesenteric nodes via pararectal and sigmoid nodes (Option B)

Lower half of the rectum & upper anal canal

Internal iliac nodes

Anal Canal (below the pectinate line)

Superficial inguinal lymph nodes (Option C)
